S2.T1.caption: TABLE I: Comparison with Related Works.
S2.T1.table:
Ref. Method Hetero-geneous models Black-box models Genera-lization bound Conver-gence Comparison with FedAL
[2] FedMD ✓ ✓ ✗ ✗ ✓
[8, 7] FD/HFD ✓ ✓ ✗ ✗ Low accuracy results
[9] FedProto ✓ ✓ ✗ ✓ Only comparable for models with same intermediate feature dimension
[13] FedGKT ✓ ✓ ✗ ✗ Not comparable because it exposes true labels to the server
[17] PerFed-CKT ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ Not comparable because it has a different objective
[6] FedZKT ✓ ✗ ✗ ✗ Not comparable
[4] FedAvg ✗ ✗ ✗ ✓ Not comparable
[10] FedDF ✓ ✗ ✓ ✗ Not comparable, but compared with a new AL extension in the paper
[11] FedGen ✗ ✗ ✓ ✗ Not comparable
[11] FedDistill+ ✓ ✗ ✗ ✗ Not comparable
[12] FedFTG ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ Not comparable
[14] FedGKD ✗ ✗ ✗ ✓ Not comparable
[19] FedCVAE N/A N/A ✗ ✗ Not comparable because it trains a separate global model
Ours FedAL ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ -
references: To demonstrate the key differences between our proposed method and existing works, we compared the proposed FedAL with the related methods in the literature, as presented in Table I. Specifically, we evaluated whether these methods support heterogeneous model architectures and black-box models among clients and whether they provide theoretical analysis on generalization bound and convergence.

references: In this section, we first formulate the collaborative learning problem and then introduce the framework of federated KD. We summarize the notation used in this paper as Table II.

S6.T3.caption: TABLE III: Results of CelebA for 10, 000 iterations.
S6.T3.table:
Method N=𝑁absentN= 20 N=𝑁absentN= 50 N=𝑁absentN= 100
FedProto 0.51 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.005 0.53 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.02 0.52 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.008
FedMD 0.51 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.02 0.64 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.01 0.66 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.01
FedAL (ours) 0.56 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.03 0.69 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.02 0.70 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.01
references:
Figure 6 shows the accuracy of FedAL and FedMD for SVHN dataset under different heterogeneity. We can observe that FedAL outperforms FedMD for varying α𝛼\alpha. Here, FedProto is not applicable for the model architectures used in SVHN, i.e., WResNet-10-1, WResnet-10-2, and WResNet-16-1, because they have different dimensions of features before the fully-connected layer.
For CIFAR-10, Figure 7 depicts the accuracy of different algorithms under different data heterogeneity levels α=5,2,𝛼52\alpha=5,2, and 1, where FedAL achieves higher accuracy than FedMD and FedProto and is more robust across different values of α𝛼\alpha.
In addition, we have run the experiments on the CelebA and CINIC-10 datasets with 10,000 iterations. Table III presents the model accuracy of different methods for CelebA. It demonstrates that FedAL can achieve a higher model accuracy compared to FedMD across different numbers of clients N𝑁N.
Table IV demonstrates the model accuracy of different methods on CINIC-10 under varying levels of data heterogeneity. We have the same observations and conclusions for CINIC-10 as other datasets.

references:
Figure 6 shows the accuracy of FedAL and FedMD for SVHN dataset under different heterogeneity. We can observe that FedAL outperforms FedMD for varying α𝛼\alpha. Here, FedProto is not applicable for the model architectures used in SVHN, i.e., WResNet-10-1, WResnet-10-2, and WResNet-16-1, because they have different dimensions of features before the fully-connected layer.
For CIFAR-10, Figure 7 depicts the accuracy of different algorithms under different data heterogeneity levels α=5,2,𝛼52\alpha=5,2, and 1, where FedAL achieves higher accuracy than FedMD and FedProto and is more robust across different values of α𝛼\alpha.
In addition, we have run the experiments on the CelebA and CINIC-10 datasets with 10,000 iterations. Table III presents the model accuracy of different methods for CelebA. It demonstrates that FedAL can achieve a higher model accuracy compared to FedMD across different numbers of clients N𝑁N.
Table IV demonstrates the model accuracy of different methods on CINIC-10 under varying levels of data heterogeneity. We have the same observations and conclusions for CINIC-10 as other datasets.

S6.T7.caption: TABLE VII: Ablation study of SVHN with α=2𝛼2\alpha=2 for 5000 iterations.
S6.T7.table:
Method FedMD FedMD-LF FedAL
Accuracy 0.722±plus-or-minus\pm0.005 0.732±plus-or-minus\pm0.004 0.744±plus-or-minus\pm0.007
references:
Ablation study.
We conduct an ablation study to verify the usefulness of all the components in the optimization objectives of FedAL.
We note that FedAL without the AL component is equivalent to FedMD-LF, and FedAL with neither the AL component or LF regularization is equivalent to FedMD. For SVHN under α=2𝛼2\alpha=2 with 5000 iterations,
we can observe from Table VII that, both LF regularization and the AL process contribute to a higher model accuracy for FedAL.
